001package io.github.ai4ci.abm;
002
003import java.util.Arrays;
004import java.util.stream.DoubleStream;
005
006import org.apache.commons.math3.analysis.UnivariateFunction;
007import org.apache.commons.math3.analysis.solvers.BrentSolver;
008import org.apache.commons.math3.exception.NoBracketingException;
009import org.slf4j.Logger;
010import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
011
012import io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.InHostConfiguration;
013import io.github.ai4ci.util.AtomicDoubleArray;
014
015/**
016 * Various utilities to calibrate model to real world observations.
017 *
018 * <p>
019 * Main purpose: provide helper functions to estimate contact rates, infer
020 * transmission parameters and compute network-based thresholds used during
021 * model calibration and sanity checks.
022 *
023 * @author Rob Challen
024 */
025public class Calibration {
026
027        /**
028         * An optimized estimator for the expected probability of transmission across
029         * a social network edge given a transmission parameter and viral load
030         * profiles.
031         *
032         * <p>
033         * This class precomputes a quartic polynomial approximation of the expected
034         * transmission probability by leveraging the structure of the Poisson
035         * binomial distribution formed by independent daily exposure risks over an
036         * infection period. For each viral load profile, the excess viral load
037         * (above threshold 1.0) is summarized into raw moments \( B_1 \)–\( B_4 \),
038         * where \( B_n = \sum_t (\delta_t)^n \) and \( \delta_t = \max(v_t - 1, 0)
039         * \).
040         *
041         * <p>
042         * The probability of at least one exposure is \( 1 - \prod_t (1 - p_t) \),
043         * with \( p_t = k \cdot c \cdot \delta_t \). Using the cumulant generating
044         * function of the Poisson binomial distribution, this is approximated as: \[
045         * \mathbb{P}(\text{any exposure}) = 1 - \exp\left( \sum_t \log(1 - p_t)
046         * \right) \] Expanding the logarithm: \[ \sum_t \log(1 - p_t) =
047         * -\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(k c)^n}{n} \sum_t (\delta_t)^n =
048         * -\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(k c)^n}{n} B_n \] Let \( S(c) = \sum_{n=1}^4
049         * \frac{(k c)^n}{n} B_n \). Then: \[ \mathbb{P}(\text{any exposure}) \approx
050         * 1 - e^{-S(c)} \] This is expanded as a power series in \( c \): \[ 1 -
051         * e^{-S(c)} = a_1 c + a_2 c^2 + a_3 c^3 + a_4 c^4 + \cdots \] The
052         * coefficients \( a_1, a_2, a_3, a_4 \) are computed using combinatorial
053         * identities from the Taylor expansion, then averaged over all contact
054         * probabilities \( k_{ij} \) and viral load profiles \( m \).
055         *
056         * <p>
057         * The final surrogate model is: \[ \hat{p}(c) = \overline{a_1} \cdot c +
058         * \overline{a_2} \cdot c^2 + \overline{a_3} \cdot c^3 + \overline{a_4} \cdot
059         * c^4 \] enabling \( O(1) \) evaluation during root-finding. This avoids
060         * repeated time-series computations, accelerating R₀ calibration while
061         * preserving accuracy for realistic parameter ranges.
062         *
063         * <p>
064         * The underlying distribution of exposures is a Poisson binomial with: \[
065         * \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_t X_t\right] = \sum_t p_t, \quad
066         * \mathrm{Var}\left[\sum_t X_t\right] = \sum_t p_t(1 - p_t), \] as
067         * referenced in the Poisson binomial distribution literature. The
068         * independence of daily exposure events justifies the additive structure of
069         * the cumulants used in the expansion.
070         *
071         * @see <a href=
072         *      "https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/93852/sum-of-bernoulli-variables-with-different-success-probabilities">Poisson
073         *      Binomial Distribution</a>
074         */
075        public static class Estimator {
076
077                /**
078                 * Precomputes the first four raw moments of the excess viral load (above
079                 * threshold 1.0) for each simulated viral load profile, used to
080                 * approximate transmission risk over time.
081                 *
082                 * <p>
083                 * For each viral load profile \( m \) , define \( \delta_t^{(m)} =
084                 * \max(v_t^{(m)} - 1, 0) \) as the excess infectiousness on day \( t \) .
085                 * The transmission probability on day \( t \) is assumed to be linear in
086                 * \( \delta_t \) : \( p_t = k \cdot c \cdot \delta_t \) , where \( k \)
087                 * is the contact probability and \( c \) is the transmission parameter.
088                 *
089                 * <p>
090                 * The probability of at least one exposure over the infectious period is:
091                 * \[ \mathbb{P}(\text{any exposure}) = 1 - \prod_{t=1}^T (1 - p_t) \]
092                 * Taking logs of the survival probability: \[ \log \mathbb{P}(\text{no
093                 * exposure}) = \sum_{t=1}^T \log(1 - p_t) = -\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(k
094                 * c)^n}{n} \sum_{t=1}^T (\delta_t)^n \] Define the \( n \) -th raw moment
095                 * of excess viral load as: \[ B_n^{(m)} = \sum_{t=1}^T (\delta_t^{(m)})^n
096                 * \] This method computes \( B_1^{(m)}, B_2^{(m)}, B_3^{(m)}, B_4^{(m)}
097                 * \) for each profile \( m \) , which capture the mean, variance-like,
098                 * skewness-like, and kurtosis-like contributions to the cumulant
099                 * structure of the underlying Poisson binomial process.
100                 *
101                 * @param viralLoadData A 100x100 array: [profile][day] of simulated viral
102                 *                      load trajectories
103                 * @return A 100x4 array: [profile][B₁, B₂, B₃, B₄], the first four raw
104                 *         moments of \( \delta_t \)
105                 */
106                private static double[][] computeBProfiles(double[][] viralLoadData) {
107                        if (viralLoadData.length != 100 || viralLoadData[0].length != 100)
108                                throw new IllegalArgumentException("Input must be a 100x100 array");
109
110                        var bProfiles = new double[100][4];
111
112                        for (var m = 0; m < 100; m++) {
113                                double B1 = 0, B2 = 0, B3 = 0, B4 = 0;
114
115                                for (var t = 0; t < 100; t++) {
116                                        var v = viralLoadData[m][t];
117                                        if (v > 1.0) {
118                                                var delta = v - 1.0;
119                                                B1 += delta;
120                                                B2 += delta * delta;
121                                                B3 += delta * delta * delta;
122                                                B4 += delta * delta * delta * delta;
123                                        }
124                                }
125
126                                bProfiles[m][0] = B1;
127                                bProfiles[m][1] = B2;
128                                bProfiles[m][2] = B3;
129                                bProfiles[m][3] = B4;
130                        }
131
132                        return bProfiles;
133                }
134
135                // Cached average polynomial coefficients: avg_c1, ..., avg_c4
136                private double avg_c1 = 0.0;
137
138                private double avg_c2 = 0.0;
139                private double avg_c3 = 0.0;
140                private double avg_c4 = 0.0;
141
142                /**
143                 * Constructor that precomputes the necessary coefficients for the
144                 * polynomial approximation of transmission probability.
145                 *
146                 * @param viralLoadProfiles    A 100x100 array of viral load trajectories
147                 *                             (profiles x time)
148                 * @param contactProbabilities An array of contact probabilities for each
149                 *                             edge in the social network
150                 */
151                public Estimator(
152                                double[][] viralLoadProfiles, double[] contactProbabilities
153                ) {
154                        var tmp = computeBProfiles(viralLoadProfiles);
155                        this.precomputeAverageCoefficients(contactProbabilities, tmp);
156                }
157
158                // Compute A(m)(c) ≈ B1*c - B2/2*c^2 + B3/6*c^3 - B4/24*c^4
159//              private static double computeA(int m, double c, double[][] bProfiles) {
160//                  double B1 = bProfiles[m][0];
161//                  double B2 = bProfiles[m][1];
162//                  double B3 = bProfiles[m][2];
163//                  double B4 = bProfiles[m][3];
164//
165//                  return B1 * c
166//                       - (B2 / 2.0) * Math.pow(c, 2)
167//                       + (B3 / 6.0) * Math.pow(c, 3)
168//                       - (B4 / 24.0) * Math.pow(c, 4);
169//              }
170
171                // Fast evaluation using cached coefficients
172                private double fastPTransmission(double c) {
173
174                        return this.avg_c1 * c + this.avg_c2 * c * c + this.avg_c3 * c * c * c
175                                        + this.avg_c4 * c * c * c * c;
176                }
177
178                /**
179                 * Precomputes the average polynomial coefficients that approximate the
180                 * expected probability of transmission across all contact edges and viral
181                 * load profiles.
182                 *
183                 * <p>
184                 * The goal is to approximate: \[ \bar{p}(c) = \frac{1}{E} \sum_{ij}
185                 * \frac{1}{M} \sum_{m=1}^M \left(1 - \prod_{t=1}^T (1 - k_{ij} c
186                 * \delta_t^{(m)})\right) \] using a quartic polynomial: \[ \bar{p}(c)
187                 * \approx a_1 c + a_2 c^2 + a_3 c^3 + a_4 c^4 \]
188                 *
189                 * <p>
190                 * Using the cumulant generating function of the Poisson binomial
191                 * distribution of exposures, we expand: \[ \mathbb{P}(\text{any
192                 * exposure}) = 1 - \exp\left( \sum_{t} \log(1 - k_{ij} c \delta_t^{(m)})
193                 * \right) \approx 1 - \exp\left( -\sum_{n=1}^4 \frac{(k_{ij} c)^n}{n}
194                 * B_n^{(m)} \right) \] Let \( S = \sum_{n=1}^4 s_n c^n \) with \( s_n =
195                 * \frac{k_{ij}^n B_n^{(m)}}{n} \) . Then: \[ 1 - e^{-S} = s_1 c +
196                 * \left(s_2 - \frac{s_1^2}{2}\right) c^2 + \left(s_3 - s_1 s_2 +
197                 * \frac{s_1^3}{6}\right) c^3 + \cdots \]
198                 *
199                 * <p>
200                 * However, the implementation uses an equivalent but algebraically
201                 * reorganized expansion, where intermediate terms \( d_n = k_{ij} \cdot
202                 * \frac{(-1)^{n+1} B_n^{(m)}}{n!} \) are used to construct the polynomial
203                 * coefficients via combinatorial identities arising from the Taylor
204                 * expansion of \( 1 - e^{-X} \) .
205                 *
206                 * <p>
207                 * This method:
208                 * <ul>
209                 * <li>Iterates over all contact probabilities \( k_{ij} \)</li>
210                 * <li>For each \( k_{ij} \) and profile \( m \) , computes local
211                 * coefficients \( c_1, c_2, c_3, c_4 \)</li>
212                 * <li>Averages them first over profiles (inner loop), then over edges
213                 * (outer loop)</li>
214                 * </ul>
215                 *
216                 * <p>
217                 * The resulting cached coefficients \( \texttt{avg\_c1}, \dots,
218                 * \texttt{avg\_c4} \) enable \( O(1) \) evaluation of the expected
219                 * transmission probability in {@link #fastPTransmission(double)}.
220                 *
221                 * @param kValues   Array of contact probabilities \( k_{ij} \) for each
222                 *                  edge in the social network
223                 * @param bProfiles Output of {@link #computeBProfiles(double[][])}: \(
224                 *                  B_1, B_2, B_3, B_4 \) per profile
225                 */
226                public void precomputeAverageCoefficients(
227                                double[] kValues, double[][] bProfiles
228                ) {
229
230                        var total_c1 = 0.0;
231                        var total_c2 = 0.0;
232                        var total_c3 = 0.0;
233                        var total_c4 = 0.0;
234
235                        for (double k_ij : kValues) {
236                                var local_c1 = 0.0;
237                                var local_c2 = 0.0;
238                                var local_c3 = 0.0;
239                                var local_c4 = 0.0;
240
241                                for (var m = 0; m < 100; m++) {
242                                        var B1 = bProfiles[m][0];
243                                        var B2 = bProfiles[m][1];
244                                        var B3 = bProfiles[m][2];
245                                        var B4 = bProfiles[m][3];
246
247                                        // Compute d_n = k_ij * a_n
248                                        var d1 = k_ij * B1;
249                                        var d2 = k_ij * (-B2 / 2.0);
250                                        var d3 = k_ij * (B3 / 6.0);
251                                        var d4 = k_ij * (-B4 / 24.0);
252
253                                        // Compute polynomial coefficients up to c^4
254                                        var c1 = d1;
255                                        var c2 = d2 - (d1 * d1) / 2.0;
256                                        var c3 = d3 - d1 * d2 + (d1 * d1 * d1) / 6.0;
257                                        var c4 = d4 - (d2 * d2) / 2.0 - d1 * d3 + (d1 * d1 * d2) / 2.0
258                                                        - (d1 * d1 * d1 * d1) / 24.0;
259
260                                        local_c1 += c1;
261                                        local_c2 += c2;
262                                        local_c3 += c3;
263                                        local_c4 += c4;
264                                }
265
266                                // Average over 100 profiles
267                                total_c1 += local_c1 / 100.0;
268                                total_c2 += local_c2 / 100.0;
269                                total_c3 += local_c3 / 100.0;
270                                total_c4 += local_c4 / 100.0;
271                        }
272
273                        // Average over all pairs
274                        this.avg_c1 = total_c1;
275                        this.avg_c2 = total_c2;
276                        this.avg_c3 = total_c3;
277                        this.avg_c4 = total_c4;
278
279                }
280        }
281
282        static Logger log = LoggerFactory.getLogger(Calibration.class);
283
284        /**
285         * Adjusts the target R0 to account for network structure effects by
286         * normalizing against the maximum possible percolation threshold of a fully
287         * connected network with the same mean degree.
288         *
289         * <p>
290         * The effective reproductive number in a network is constrained by its
291         * topology. The percolation threshold \( T_c = \langle k \rangle / (\langle
292         * k^2 \rangle - \langle k \rangle) \) determines the minimum
293         * transmissibility for an epidemic. In a fully connected network with
294         * homogeneous contact probability, \( \langle k^2 \rangle = \langle k
295         * \rangle^2 \), so: \[ T_{\text{max}} = \frac{\langle k \rangle}{\langle k
296         * \rangle^2 - \langle k \rangle} = \frac{1}{\langle k \rangle - 1} \]
297         *
298         * <p>
299         * This method computes the ratio of the actual percolation threshold \( T_c
300         * \) to \( T_{\text{max}} \), which captures how much the network structure
301         * reduces or enhances transmission potential. The adjusted \( R_0 \) is
302         * then: \[ R_0^{\text{adj}} = R_0 \cdot \frac{T_c}{T_{\text{max}}} \]
303         *
304         * <p>
305         * This adjustment ensures that the calibrated transmission parameter
306         * reflects only the biological mechanism (viral load → transmissibility),
307         * decoupled from network-specific structural effects. It allows for
308         * transferable parameter estimates across different population structures.
309         *
310         * <p>
311         * For example, a clustered or sparse network will have \( T_c >
312         * T_{\text{max}} \), leading to \( R_0^{\text{adj}} \lt R_0 \), meaning a
313         * higher intrinsic transmissibility is needed to achieve the same
314         * population-level \( R_0 \).
315         *
316         * @param o  the outbreak configuration
317         * @param R0 the desired basic reproduction number in a well-mixed population
318         * @return the network-adjusted R0 that compensates for reduced connectivity
319         */
320        public static double adjustR0(Outbreak o, double R0) {
321                // N.B. this is the average percolation threshold (average of average
322                // contact
323                // network degree ....)
324                var k = averageContactDegree(o);
325                var perc = percolationThreshold(o);
326                // This is the percolation of a network
327                var maxPerc = k / (k * k - k);
328                return R0 * perc / maxPerc;
329        }
330
331        /**
332         * Compute the average contact degree across the population.
333         *
334         * @param o the outbreak providing the social network
335         * @return the average node degree (expected contacts per person)
336         */
337        public static double averageContactDegree(Outbreak o) {
338                var nodeDegree = networkDegreePerPerson(o);
339                return DoubleStream.of(nodeDegree).average().orElse(0);
340        }
341
342        /**
343         * Estimate the average number of contacts per person per day based on the
344         * outbreak social network and individual mobility baselines.
345         *
346         * @param outbreak the outbreak containing the social network and people
347         * @return the mean number of contacts per person per day
348         */
349        public static double contactsPerPersonPerDay(Outbreak outbreak) {
350
351                var social = outbreak.getSocialNetwork();
352                var totalContactProbability = social.parallelStream().mapToDouble(r -> {
353                        Person person1 = r.getSource(outbreak);
354                        Person person2 = r.getTarget(outbreak);
355                        return r.contactProbability(
356                                        person1.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline(),
357                                        person2.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline()
358                        );
359                }).sum();
360                // Each contact involves 2 people so we have to count them twice
361                return totalContactProbability * 2 / outbreak.getPeople().size();
362
363        }
364
365        /**
366         * Identifies for a given transmission parameter, the expected number of
367         * exposures per infection, given social network topology and baseline
368         * contact probability between agents.
369         *
370         * @param outbreak  the outbreak providing the social network and population
371         * @param dd        an array of viral load profiles (profiles x time)
372         * @param parameter the transmission parameter to evaluate (scales
373         *                  transmissibility)
374         * @return the expected number of exposures generated by a single infection
375         */
376        public static double expectedExposuresPerInfection(
377                        Outbreak outbreak, double[][] dd, double parameter
378        ) {
379
380                return outbreak.getSocialNetwork().parallelStream().mapToDouble(r -> {
381                        var person1 = r.getSource(outbreak);
382                        var person2 = r.getTarget(outbreak);
383                        // Per day probability of contact between two people (baseline) on any
384                        // day
385                        // This is equivalent to what happens in {@link Contact#contactNetwork}
386                        var pContact = r.contactProbability(
387                                        person1.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline(),
388                                        person2.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline()
389                        );
390
391                        var meanPAnyExposure = Arrays.stream(dd).parallel()
392                                        .mapToDouble(
393                                                        profile -> pAnyExposure(pContact, profile, parameter)
394                                        ).average().orElse(0);
395
396                        // This is the probability that an exposure passes over a
397                        // single edge in the social network graph (assuming that
398                        // one end of the edge is infected) it takes into account
399                        // the probability of contact and the delay in transmission
400                        // due to the in host (i.e. it is aggregated in time - like R0)
401                        return meanPAnyExposure;
402
403                })
404                                .map(
405                                                d -> d * outbreak.getSocialNetwork().size() * 2
406                                                                / outbreak.getPopulationSize()
407                                ).average().getAsDouble();
408                // So here we need to look at spread of distribution in a way
409                // that is deterministic.
410
411                // factor of 2 because each edge has 2 vertices
412                // so over all the edges in the social network the expected flux of
413                // the infection is the sum of the probability of exposures. This
414                // flux represents the networks capacity for next generation size
415                // assuming some sort of random state in previous generation
416                // or more accurately the sum of all possible states where 1 person
417                // is infected
418
419                // This distribution is likely to be very skewed (maybe depending
420                // on the network. Also the exposures of exposures is going to be
421                // much larger again if there is any degree of correlation in the
422                // node degree
423        }
424
425        /**
426         * Calibrate severity cutoffs for events based on probability. Events might
427         * be hospitalisation, death, and be relative to infection so always a number
428         * less than 1. A small IFR correlates with a high cutoff for severity based
429         * on population severity distribution. Therefore for a 0.01 IFR we cut-off
430         * at the 0.99 quantile for severity.
431         *
432         * @param outbreak            the outbreak
433         * @param infectionEventRatio a ratio between infected and those infected and
434         *                            e.g. hospitalised.
435         * @return the severity cutoff value (unit interval) corresponding to the
436         *         supplied ratio
437         */
438        public static double inferSeverityCutoff(
439                        Outbreak outbreak, double infectionEventRatio
440        ) {
441
442                var dist = InHostConfiguration.getPeakSeverity(
443                                outbreak.getExecutionConfiguration().getInHostConfiguration(),
444                                outbreak.getExecutionConfiguration(), 1000, 50
445                );
446                // N.B. only interested in the in host peak hence we can use a shorter
447                // duration.
448                var tmp = dist.getQuantile(1 - infectionEventRatio);
449                return tmp;
450        }
451
452        /**
453         * The translation and the in host model viral load and transmission
454         * probability is a function
455         * {@link OutbreakBaseline#transmissibilityFromViralLoad(double, double)}.
456         * The in host viral load model has been run for a range of different
457         * parameters and the average response held in the viral load profile. The
458         * probability of a contact that generates one or more exposures over the
459         * whole infective period is calculated. The R0 value is the population
460         * average of the sum of each individuals secondary exposures. This is solved
461         * for R0 to get a parameter of the function that converts viral load to
462         * transmission probability per day. This ignores the possibility of multiple
463         * exposure by different people, but this is OK for R0 calibration.
464         *
465         * <br>
466         * The calculation requires a set of viral load profiles based on a random
467         * sampling of 100 average people, exposed to a 1 unit dose of virus which is
468         * handled by
469         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.InHostConfiguration#getViralLoadProfile(io.github.ai4ci.config.ExecutionConfiguration, int, int)
470         * the in host model configuration}
471         *
472         * @param outbreak the outbreak configuration to use for calibration
473         * @param R0       the target basic reproduction number to match
474         * @return the inferred transmission parameter
475         */
476        public static double inferViralLoadTransmissionParameter(
477                        Outbreak outbreak, double R0
478        ) {
479
480                // So we need to forward simulate the number of exposures given viral load
481                // for
482                // every potential contact in the outbreak
483                var dd = outbreak.getExecutionConfiguration().getViralLoadProfile();
484                return inferViralLoadTransmissionParameter(outbreak, dd, R0);
485        }
486
487        /**
488         * Infer the viral load transmission parameter for a supplied viral load
489         * profile set.
490         *
491         * @param outbreak the outbreak configuration providing network and execution
492         *                 settings
493         * @param dd       an array of viral load profiles (profiles x time)
494         * @param R0       the target basic reproduction number to match
495         * @return the inferred transmission parameter
496         */
497        public static double inferViralLoadTransmissionParameter(
498                        Outbreak outbreak, double[][] dd, double R0
499        ) {
500                var solver = new BrentSolver(0.001);
501                var adjR0 = adjustR0(outbreak, R0);
502                UnivariateFunction fnR0 = (toInfer) -> {
503                        return expectedExposuresPerInfection(outbreak, dd, toInfer) - adjR0;
504                };
505
506                log.info(
507                                "Max R0 for this network is: " + expectedExposuresPerInfection(
508                                                outbreak, dd, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY
509                                )
510                );
511
512                try {
513                        var inferred = solver.solve(10000, fnR0, 0, 1);
514                        log.info(
515                                        "P(transmission|infectious contact with viral load 1.5): {}, for RO: {} (adjusted for network: {})",
516                                        String.format(
517                                                        "%1.4f",
518                                                        OutbreakBaseline
519                                                                        .transmissibilityFromViralLoad(1.5, inferred)
520                                        ), R0, adjR0
521                        );
522                        return inferred;
523                } catch (NoBracketingException e) {
524                        throw new RuntimeException("No solution for R0 in the range 0 to 1");
525                }
526
527        }
528
529        /**
530         * Infers the viral load transmission parameter that achieves a target R₀
531         * using a fast, polynomial-based approximation.
532         *
533         * <p>
534         * This method is an optimized alternative to
535         * {@link #inferViralLoadTransmissionParameter(Outbreak, double)}. It uses
536         * the {@link Estimator} class to approximate the expected number of
537         * secondary exposures per infection via a precomputed quartic polynomial in
538         * the transmission parameter. The approximation is derived from a series
539         * expansion of the probability of at least one exposure over time,
540         * accounting for variable daily transmissibility and contact probability.
541         *
542         * <p>
543         * The method adjusts the target R₀ for network structure using
544         * {@link #adjustR0(Outbreak, double)} and solves for the transmission
545         * parameter using Brent's method. The result is significantly faster than
546         * the full simulation-based approach, making it suitable for repeated
547         * calibration tasks.
548         *
549         * @param outbreak the outbreak configuration, including social network and
550         *                 viral load profiles
551         * @param R0       the desired basic reproduction number to calibrate to
552         * @return the inferred transmission parameter (scales transmissibility per
553         *         unit viral load above 1.0)
554         * @throws RuntimeException if no solution is found within the valid
555         *                          parameter range [0, 0.1]
556         */
557        public static double inferViralLoadTransmissionParameterQuick(
558                        Outbreak outbreak, double R0
559        ) {
560                var viralLoadProfile = outbreak.getExecutionConfiguration()
561                                .getViralLoadProfile();
562                var contactProbability = outbreak.getSocialNetwork().parallelStream()
563                                .mapToDouble(r -> {
564                                        Person person1 = r.getSource(outbreak);
565                                        Person person2 = r.getTarget(outbreak);
566                                        // Per day probability of contact between two people (baseline)
567                                        // on any day
568                                        // This is equivalent to what happens in {@link
569                                        // Contact#contactNetwork}
570                                        return r.contactProbability(
571                                                        person1.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline(),
572                                                        person2.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline()
573                                        );
574                                }).toArray();
575                var est = new Estimator(viralLoadProfile, contactProbability);
576                var solver = new BrentSolver(0.001);
577                var adjR0 = adjustR0(outbreak, R0);
578                long countAgents = outbreak.getPopulationSize();
579                UnivariateFunction fnR0 = (toInfer) -> {
580                        return est.fastPTransmission(toInfer) * 2 / countAgents - adjR0;
581                };
582
583                try {
584                        var inferred = solver.solve(10000, fnR0, 0, 0.1);
585                        log.info(
586                                        "P(transmission|infectious contact with viral load 1.5): {}, for RO: {} (adjusted for network: {})",
587                                        String.format(
588                                                        "%1.4f",
589                                                        OutbreakBaseline
590                                                                        .transmissibilityFromViralLoad(1.5, inferred)
591                                        ), R0, adjR0
592                        );
593                        return inferred;
594                } catch (NoBracketingException e) {
595                        throw new RuntimeException("No solution for R0 in the range 0 to 1");
596                }
597        }
598
599        /**
600         * Compute the maximum achievable basic reproduction number (R0) for this
601         * network assuming transmission on every edge.
602         *
603         * @param outbreak the outbreak configuration with network and viral profiles
604         * @return the maximum R0 the network topology can support
605         */
606        public static double maxR0(Outbreak outbreak) {
607                var dd = outbreak.getExecutionConfiguration().getViralLoadProfile();
608                return expectedExposuresPerInfection(
609                                outbreak, dd, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY
610                );
611        }
612
613        /**
614         * Node (aka Person) temporal contact network degree based on probabilistic
615         * weighting of social network. This is a mean estimate of the degree of
616         * contact network for each node based on a single bernouilli trial for each
617         * social network edge with a per edge probability. The distribution would be
618         * the sum of bernoullis with different probabilities which is a Poisson
619         * Binomial Distribution
620         * {@see https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/93852/sum-of-bernoulli-variables-with-different-success-probabilities}
621         *
622         * @param o the outbreak providing the social network and people
623         * @return array of per-person expected contact degrees
624         */
625        public static double[] networkDegreePerPerson(Outbreak o) {
626                var degrees = new AtomicDoubleArray(o.getPopulationSize());
627
628                o.getSocialNetwork().parallelStream().forEach(r -> {
629                        var person1 = r.getSource(o);
630                        var person2 = r.getTarget(o);
631                        var p = r.contactProbability(
632                                        person1.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline(),
633                                        person2.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline()
634                        );
635                        degrees.addAndGet(person1.getId(), p);
636                        degrees.addAndGet(person2.getId(), p);
637
638                });
639                return degrees.toArray();
640        }
641
642        // Utility for aggregating risk of exposure over one viral load profile.
643        private static double pAnyExposure(
644                        double pContact, double[] profile, double parameter
645        ) {
646                var pNonExposure = 1D; // pNonExposure
647                for (double viralLoad : profile) {
648                        // In the main simulation this transmissibility value is modified by
649                        // various odds ratios
650                        var pExposureGivenContact = OutbreakBaseline
651                                        .transmissibilityFromViralLoad(viralLoad, parameter);
652                        pNonExposure = pNonExposure * (1 - pContact * pExposureGivenContact);
653                }
654                return 1 - pNonExposure;
655        }
656
657        /**
658         * Computes the percolation threshold of the probabilistic contact network
659         * using the second moment of the degree distribution.
660         *
661         * <p>
662         * In epidemic percolation theory, the threshold for sustained transmission
663         * is determined by the structure of the contact network. For a random
664         * network, the critical transmissibility \( T_c \) at which a giant
665         * connected component emerges is: \[ T_c = \frac{\langle k \rangle}{\langle
666         * k^2 \rangle - \langle k \rangle} \] where \( \langle k \rangle \) is the
667         * mean degree and \( \langle k^2 \rangle \) is the second moment of the
668         * degree distribution.
669         *
670         * <p>
671         * In this model, contact between agents is probabilistic, so the degree of
672         * each node is a sum of independent Bernoulli variables with different
673         * success probabilities \( p_{ij} \), forming a <i>Poisson binomial
674         * distribution</i>. The expected degree of node \( i \) is: \[
675         * \mathbb{E}[k_i] = \sum_{j} p_{ij} \] and the variance is: \[
676         * \mathrm{Var}(k_i) = \sum_{j} p_{ij}(1 - p_{ij}) \] as per the properties
677         * of the Poisson binomial distribution.
678         *
679         * <p>
680         * The second moment \( \langle k^2 \rangle \) is estimated as: \[ \langle
681         * k^2 \rangle = \langle k \rangle^2 + \langle \mathrm{Var}(k_i) \rangle \]
682         * where the latter term accounts for the excess variance due to
683         * heterogeneous \( p_{ij} \).
684         *
685         * <p>
686         * This method computes the average percolation threshold across the
687         * population, reflecting the network's susceptibility to epidemic spread. A
688         * lower threshold implies higher connectivity and easier outbreak
689         * propagation.
690         *
691         * @param o the outbreak configuration, including the social network and
692         *          agent mobility
693         * @return the percolation threshold \(T_c\) for the network
694         *
695         * @see <a href=
696         *      "https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/93852/sum-of-bernoulli-variables-with-different-success-probabilities">Poisson
697         *      Binomial Distribution</a>
698         */
699        public static double percolationThreshold(Outbreak o) {
700
701                var degrees = new AtomicDoubleArray(o.getPopulationSize());
702                var variances = new AtomicDoubleArray(o.getPopulationSize());
703
704                o.getSocialNetwork().parallelStream().forEach(r -> {
705                        var person1 = r.getSource(o);
706                        var person2 = r.getTarget(o);
707                        var p = r.contactProbability(
708                                        person1.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline(),
709                                        person2.getBaseline().getMobilityBaseline()
710                        );
711                        degrees.addAndGet(person1.getId(), p);
712                        variances.addAndGet(person1.getId(), p * (1 - p));
713                        degrees.addAndGet(person2.getId(), p);
714                        variances.addAndGet(person2.getId(), p * (1 - p));
715                });
716                // N.B. this is the average percolation threshold (average of average
717                // contact
718                // network degree ....
719                var k = degrees.stream().average().orElse(0);
720                // Technically this should be the average of the product of the same
721                // Poisson Binomial Distributions, which is going to be wider than this.
722                var varK = degrees.stream().average().orElse(0);
723                var k2 = degrees.stream().map(d -> d * d).average().orElse(0) + varK;
724                return k / (k2 - k);
725        }
726
727        /**
728         * As per Koch et al 2013, Edge removal in contact networks eqn 2
729         *
730         * @param R0 the desired basic reproduction number
731         * @param o  the outbreak providing network information
732         * @return the per-edge transmission probability corresponding to R0
733         */
734        public static double perEdgeTransmissionProbability(double R0, Outbreak o) {
735                var Tc = percolationThreshold(o);
736                return R0 * Tc;
737        }
738
739}
